Introduction to Amantadine

Amantadine is a medication used to treat Parkinson's disease, as well as other conditions such as influenza A and drug-induced extrapyramidal reactions. It is believed to work by increasing the levels of dopamine in the brain, which helps to improve symptoms of Parkinson's disease.

Mechanism of Action

Amantadine's exact mechanism of action is not fully understood, but it is thought to:
  • Block the N-methyl-D-aspartate (NMDA) receptor, which can help to reduce symptoms of Parkinson's disease
  • Increase the release of dopamine, a neurotransmitter that is involved in movement and coordination
  • Have anticholinergic effects, which can help to reduce tremors and other symptoms of Parkinson's disease

Common Side Effects of Amantadine

Some common side effects of amantadine include:
  • Dizziness or lightheadedness
  • Nausea or vomiting
  • Headache
  • Fatigue
  • Insomnia or vivid dreams

Severe Side Effects of Amantadine

Some severe side effects of amantadine include:
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a rare but life-threatening condition
  • Seizures or convulsions
  • Psychotic episodes, such as hallucinations or delusions
  • Orthostatic hypotension, which can increase the risk of falls

Management Strategies for Adverse Effects

To manage adverse effects of amantadine, it is essential to:
  • Start with a low dose and gradually increase as needed and tolerated
  • Take the medication with food to reduce nausea and vomiting
  • Avoid standing up quickly to reduce the risk of orthostatic hypotension
  • Report any severe side effects to a healthcare provider immediately

Importance of Consulting Healthcare Providers

It is crucial to consult a healthcare provider before taking amantadine, especially if you have a history of:
  • Seizures or epilepsy
  • Psychiatric disorders, such as schizophrenia or bipolar disorder
  • Kidney or liver disease
  • Pregnancy or breastfeeding
Your healthcare provider can help you weigh the benefits and risks of amantadine and monitor you for any adverse effects.

Drug Interactions

Amantadine can interact with other medications, including:
  • Anticholinergics, such as trihexyphenidyl, which can increase the risk of side effects
  • Antipsychotics, such as haloperidol, which can increase the risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Stimulants, such as amphetamines, which can increase the risk of seizures or psychotic episodes
It is essential to inform your healthcare provider about all medications you are taking before starting amantadine.
